image.altText: A man wearing a suit stands in front of the Australian emblem holding  a report.

items.synopsis: These major budget measures reveal the type of plan the federal government has for Australia, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: What's in the budget? Here are some of the major measures we know about

image.altText: Trenton Hoare wears a black t-shirt and looks at the camera

items.synopsis: If you don't have a rental history it can be very hard to break into the rental market. A new program for young renters will help them get a foot in the door.

title.children: Housing affordability and no rental history is a double whammy for young people

image.altText: Black and white photo of Victoria Cafasso wearing a striped Donald and Daisy Duck top.

items.synopsis: New forensic technology will be used to re-examine all Tasmanian cold cases, with police hoping it could finally provide answers to families and loved ones of those like Victoria, whose killer has never been found.

title.children: Could the question of who killed Victoria be solved with Tasmania's new forensic technology?

image.altText: A girl standing next to a car.

items.synopsis: Child safety departments knowingly leave some children with carers who have had serious concerns raised about them, insiders say. In some states, foster and kinship carers don't even have a working with children check.

title.children: Alyssa grew up in an affluent suburb. She knows people don't see what's 'behind closed doors'

image.altText: Man with Ukraine flag patch on uniform in foreground with damaged apartment building in background

items.synopsis: Russia had fired 60 Iranian-made kamikaze drones, including 36 at Kyiv — all of which have been shot down — as the Kremlin enacted a major security clampdown ahead of annual May 9 Victory Day celebrations by curbing the use of drones and ride-sharing services in its largest cities.

title.children: Russia launches swarm of kamikaze drones at Ukraine, cancels some annual Victory Day parades

image.altText: A tight shot of Jim Chalmers head, he wears a suit and red tie stands in front of a blue curtain

items.synopsis: When Jim Chalmers outlines his bold plan it will fire a debate about whether we are providing a cure for the nation's ills or merely kicking the can down the road, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Will the federal budget's relief package solve a problem or ignore it?

image.altText: A woman points her finger.

items.synopsis: With an expected $4 billion budget surplus, the government comes under fire from Tasmanian senator Jacqui Lambie for withholding spending on Australia's most vulnerable.

title.children: 'Done nothing': Lambie attacks government ahead of expected budget surplus

image.altText: Valery Gerasimov sits at a desk wearing military uniform.

items.synopsis: In authoritarian regimes, competent soldiers are less important than loyal ones. And, as Russia's General Valery Gerasimov may find out in the future, they also make excellent scapegoats for tyrants wishing to save their own skin, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Why this Russian general may be Ukraine's greatest asset

image.altText: Budget tree

items.synopsis: If the federal government's forecast is realised, Jim Chalmers would be the first treasurer to deliver a surplus since Peter Costello.

title.children: Federal budget to forecast first surplus in 15 years

image.altText: A composite of Mariah Carey smiling and Jason Alexander smiling.

items.synopsis: For a generation of people in both Australia and the US, the name Jenny Craig became synonymous with weight loss. But now it's closing shop in the US as some experts fear where diet culture is headed from here.

title.children: The Jenny Craig collapse in the US highlights how diet culture is the 'monster that just keeps morphing'

image.altText: A close-up of the Qantas logo on the tail of one of its planes. The sky behind it is clear.

items.synopsis: The long-running battle between Qantas and the Transport Workers' Union over the sacking of 1,700 ground staff at the height of the pandemic moves to the High Court in Canberra.

title.children: High Court to hear battle between Qantas and Transport Workers' Union over ground crew outsourcing

image.altText: Unidentified male wearing a hoodie.

items.synopsis: In Tasmania, social housing is in short supply and efforts are being made to build new homes as quickly as possible. But as soon as construction starts, it is targeted by teenage vandals.

title.children: Groups of roaming juveniles 'continually committing offences', Tasmanian Police association says

image.altText: a composite image of two boys facing away from the camera. their identities cannot be made out

items.synopsis: A neighbour of two teenagers with autism found locked in a room and severely malnourished in 2020, has detailed the horrific conditions they were subjected to. WARNING: This story contains content readers may find distressing.

title.children: Neighbour tells disability royal commission of horrific conditions teen boys were held in

image.altText: Two people wearing full body protective suits cross a road carrying yellow garbage bags

items.synopsis: Experts believe knowledge sharing and collaboration between countries and research organisations are the best ways to prevent the outbreak of future pandemics.

title.children: Ancient bacteria immune to antibiotics have been found in the Arctic. Can we protect ourselves if they spread?

image.altText: A girl with curly hair hugs her mum who is wearing sunglasses and a denim jacket.

items.synopsis: Ash and her young daughter Clancy caught influenza after they forgot to get vaccinated last year. She never wants to experience it again. So why are so many Aussie kids not getting their flu shot?

title.children: The McLeods forgot to get their flu vaccine last year. It led to young Clancy being bedridden

image.altText: An aerial view of Alice Springs by night.

items.synopsis: Details of tens of millions of dollars in funding to improve safety in the embattled town, announced by the prime minister in February, will be revealed for the first time in the federal budget.

title.children: Alice Springs social woes to receive big budget spend, but $100m of promised funds still missing

image.altText: Sharks under a boat.

items.synopsis: Fishers say they're losing more and more fish to sharks. While some are calling for increased fishing quotas or culls, researchers say there's no simple answer.

title.children: Australia has one of the world’s strictest shark fisheries. But anglers say shark numbers are out of control

image.altText: Row of large homes along waterfront with boats moored out front

items.synopsis: Two of Queensland's most sought-after regions have an estimated 10,000 properties locked up as short-stay accommodation, but affordable housing advocates say holiday lets are not the driving force behind the rental shortage.

title.children: Why AirBNBs and short-stays don't deserve all the blame for Noosa rental shortage

image.altText: A smiling woman.

items.synopsis: Marisa Batti has had dermal filler injections since she turned 18. But after filler blocked a blood vessel, she wants other people to be aware of the risks.

title.children: This popular cosmetic injection procedure is linked to 12 reports of blindness

image.altText: A thick blanket of snow lines a footpath in a park with snow on trees in the background.

items.synopsis: A cold front brings icy weather, snow and hail to large swathes of the country, with some places clocking record cold temperatures for May. The BOM is warning the cold snap isn't over yet.

title.children: Cold front delivers snow and hail to large parts of Australia, with more cold weather to come

image.altText: ACT DPP Shane Drumgold at board of inquiry

items.synopsis: Questioned about an Australian Federal Police report that described Brittany Higgins as "manipulative", ACT Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold tells a Board of Inquiry into the case that it contained "basic, misguided analysis".

title.children: 'Misguided': ACT top prosecutor dismisses AFP report that described Brittany Higgins as 'manipulative'

image.altText: the outside of the opera house sails as people walk past

items.synopsis: More than 3 million Australians watched King Charles's coronation, with Parliament House among the many significant buildings across the country lit up, but those in Sydney remained in the dark.

title.children: Chris Minns stands by keeping Opera House sails unlit for coronation, as monarchists 'condemn' decision

image.altText: Two men in suits shake hands as they meet ouside under a grey sky.

items.synopsis: Beijing accuses Australia of trying to sabotage its relationship with Fiji as questions swirl over whether the Pacific Island country will cut security ties with Beijing.

title.children: China says Australia is disrupting Fiji relationship, amid police deal uncertainty

image.altText: Man with glasses smiles for the camera - the face of the person next to him is pixelated.

items.synopsis: The first call for help to the ambulance service suggested Jarred Antonovich, who had a swollen face and was in "discomfort", was suffering an asthma attack.

title.children: Paramedics not told about dying man's use of powerful psychedelic and Kambo frog poison

image.altText: Melanie Morris and her nine year-old daughter, Kaitlyn Morris 1

items.synopsis: Melanie Morris vividly remembers the sense of searing anger as she held her sick toddler in her arms in the emergency department of Launceston's general hospital for the fourth time in a week, back in 2015. Years on, the question is — are things getting any better?

title.children: 'I'm a doctor, you're only a mother': Melanie had to fight to get her barely responsive child an X-ray for an obstruction

image.altText: An Australian LNG ship sails off the coast of Western Australia.

items.synopsis: Tuesday's federal budget will include changes to a key tax levied on gas exporters, aimed at bringing billions in additional revenue to the budget over the next few years. But some say it still falls too far short.

title.children: The government is jacking up taxes on the gas industry. What's set to change, and how much money will it bring in?

image.altText: A masked police officer with his arms folded, police tape across a footpath

items.synopsis: An electrician who "caused irreparable damage" to a woman in a WA tourist town had fallen asleep in a park in the hours before the attack, a court has heard.

title.children: Electrician remembers 'fear in her eyes, screaming' after jogger sex attack

image.altText: a man in handcuffs taken by police away from court into a police wagon

items.synopsis: The victim says she had the "world at her feet" before the night of the assault and has found social media comments about her case "extremely difficult".

title.children: Woman sexually assaulted by Jarryd Hayne speaks out about 'never-ending nightmare'

image.altText: A man in teal and black football guernsey and hat kicking on a field.

items.synopsis: The Port Adelaide Football Club has condemned a racist post directed towards Indigenous AFL player Junior Rioli.

title.children: Port Adelaide calls out 'reprehensible behaviour' against Indigenous player

image.altText: A close-up, side-on shot of a smiling middle-aged man with fair hair and a dark-coloured suit in Perth's CBD, near another man.

items.synopsis: A fly-in fly-out worker is on trial in WA's District Court accused of sexually assaulting a colleague at a remote mine site in the state's Pilbara region.

title.children: 'I felt like a cement slab was on top of me': Woman tells of alleged rape at BHP mine site

image.altText: A woman in a police uniform standing in front of a microphone next to a man in a blue shirt

items.synopsis: Police and human rights advocates warn against vigilante behaviour after a group of residents marched on the homes of alleged offenders following an anti-crime rally in Rockhampton, on one occasion chasing a person down the street.

title.children: Police call for calm after angry locals rally against crime in Central Queensland

image.altText: A man being arrested standing by a police van with his face pixellated

items.synopsis: WA's Corruption and Crime Commission finds a police officer engaged in serious misconduct by pulling, punching and swearing at a man during an arrest in Mirrabooka in Perth's north.

title.children: WA police officer used ‘insulting and offensive’ language after striking man he was arresting, corruption watchdog finds

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says that Labor inherited a trillion dollars of "Liberal debt" when it came to office, and that Labor's share of that, left to the previous Coalition government was "a tiny fraction". RMIT ABC Fact Check runs the numbers.

title.children: We fact checked Jim Chalmers on the amount of debt Labor left the Coalition. Here's what we found

image.altText: Rocket Lab's Electron rocket can be seen before launch near the coast of Mahia, New Zealand

items.synopsis: New storm trackers launched from New Zealand's North Island will help give hourly updates of tropical cyclones, rather than the six hourly updates provided by current satellites.

title.children: Cyclone-monitoring satellites launched by NASA from New Zealand

image.altText: A close-up photograph of Joon Seong Tan, who is looking at the camera with a neutral expression.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors allege Joon Seong Tan murdered Ju "Kelly" Zhang, a woman he'd dated for a few weeks, later using his phone to search the term: "How many years for killing a person in Australia?"

title.children: Jealous man killed Melbourne mother and disposed of body in bin, court told
